answers.answer: As a former Air Force member I have seen a few people with "Gulf War Syndrome".  I am so glad that I was very fortunate not to have to go over to the desert the 10 years I was in.  I was diagnosed with Graves Disease in Sep 06 and thyca a few months later.  I started getting night sweats after my TT and RAI, but that could also be cause by being kicked into menopause at 46.  It sounds like  your husband's whole endocrine system is messed up.It's a shame the government won't admit to all the **** that those serving in the Gulf was exposed to.  I co-worker of mine has memory problems associated from GWS.  I tell her that's how I feel with my brain fog.Does your husband's endo specialize in thyroid problems?  Some endo's specialize in diabetes and know have a good understanding of thryroid issues.  My advice is for your husband to keep a journal of his symptoms as he experiences them since he has memory problems.  Maybe this could help him explain to his doctors what he is going thru and help them provide better care.Sorry I can't offer much more advice than that.  Just know that we are all here for you guys.  Maybe you might want to suggest to your hubby to come to the board himself.  It really truly helps to know that your talking with people who are going thru the same kind of problems. We here to provide support to fellow thyroid disorder sufferers AND their loved ones.  So ask your questions...we may not know all the answers, but we all know how to send lots of e-hugs and support.MJ

question: My husband was diagnosed with Graves Disease two years ago.  Since then, he has had both of his hips replaced due to osteoporosis (parathyroid problems) had his thyroid removed and has serious memory loss.  He is 42 years old and prior to finding out about his thyroid problem was in wonderful health.  Now we have very serious concerns about his testosterone levels.  His doctor was trying to find out why my husband has bed soaking night sweats every night - he ran some hormone levels.  His testosterone level was low, so he started him on Andro Gel.  Three weeks later they retested his levels and they were even lower!  We see a neurologist, endocrinologist and now have two orthopedic surgeons that we deal with (my husband just went through shoulder surgery due to a compressed joint and numerous subchondral cysts).  His current med list is Topamax 200 mg per day, Citalopram 40 mg per day, Calcium with D three times per day, Nexium, levothyroxine 250 mcg per day.He served in the Persian Gulf War in 1991 and was a patient at the VA for a couple of years until I found a job with health insurance benefits.  By the way, the VA would never admit to my husband contracting any type of illness from his service in the war.  Anyway, we are all baffled as to what is happening and we could use any advice you could supply to us.  We are afraid that he's getting worse and we don't know what to do.  Thank you.
title: can the pituitary gland cause graves disease?
